Description: Survivors of childhood cancer are at increased risk for chronic health conditions (CHCs) and early mortality at rates typically seen among individuals decades older, suggesting an accelerated aging phenotype.  We measured multiple biomarkers of aging, including leukocyte telomere length, epigenetic age and clonal hematopoiesis, to demonstrate the phenomenon of accelerated aging, evaluate the influence of cancer treatment exposures, health behaviors and social determinants of health, and further assess how these aging biomarkers are associated with specific CHCs, severity/burden of all CHCs, and premature mortality among childhood cancer survivors.
SearchResultBody: ME01. Aging Biomarkers and Accelerated Aging as a New Paradigm for Clinical Research in Survivors of Childhood Cancer
Title: Aging Biomarkers and Accelerated Aging as a New Paradigm for Clinical Research in Survivors of Childhood Cancer
